questions.text: Acute sudden painful diminution of vision with vertically oval pupil is caused by: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Angle closure glaucoma

 

Angle closure glaucoma is a condition where there is a sudden increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to the closure of the angle between the iris and the cornea, which obstructs the drainage of aqueous humor. This leads to a rapid rise in IOP, resulting in acute, severe eye pain, headache, nausea, and a sudden loss of vision. A key clinical sign of an acute angle closure glaucoma attack is a mid-dilated, vertically oval, and sluggishly reacting pupil. The vertically oval pupil occurs due to ischemia of the iris sphincter muscles caused by the high IOP.

 

 

This condition is an ophthalmic emergency, and immediate treatment is necessary to prevent permanent vision loss. The high IOP can cause damage to the optic nerve, leading to irreversible vision loss if not promptly managed.

 

Note - Vogt's triad is a set of three clinical signs associated with the aftermath of an acute attack of glaucoma. This triad includes sphincter atrophy (damage to the iris sphincter muscle), a mid-dilated pupil that does not react well to light, and glaucoma flecken, which are patches of pigmentation or discoloration on the lens of the eye resulting from the damage caused by the increased intraocular pressure during a glaucoma attack.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CSR/Macular degeneration: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) and age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) are conditions that cause a gradual, painless loss of central vision. They do not present with acute pain, sudden vision loss, or pupillary abnormalities like a vertically oval pupil.

 

Option B. Cataract: Cataracts cause a gradual, painless decrease in vision due to the clouding of the lens. They do not cause sudden vision loss, pain, or changes in pupil shape.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve that can cause sudden vision loss and pain, particularly with eye movement. However, it does not cause changes in the shape of the pupil or a vertically oval pupil. The pain in optic neuritis is typically associated with eye movements rather than the constant severe pain seen in angle closure glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute angle closure glaucoma is characterized by sudden, painful vision loss, and a mid-dilated, vertically oval, sluggishly reacting pupil. Recognizing these signs is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of loose stools with an increase in frequency for 4 days. On examination, he is drowsy, unable to feed, and skin on pinching goes back very slowly. According to the integrated management of neonatal and childhood illness (IMNCI), this child will be classified as having: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Severe dehydration

 

A clinical scenario of a dehydrated child who is drowsy and not able to feed with skin going back very slowly on pinching is suggestive of severe dehydration (as per IMNCI).

 

 

Diarrhea is a condition characterized by a change in the frequency and consistency of stools, occurring more than 3 times a day. Dysentery is a type of diarrhea that is associated with the presence of blood in stools. If the condition subsides within 7 days, it is termed as acute diarrhea, whereas if it persists for more than 2 weeks, it is termed as persistent diarrhea.

 

Acute diarrhea is commonly caused by intestinal infections, with rotavirus and enterotoxigenic E. coli being the major infectious agents. Other causes of acute diarrhea include certain drugs, food allergies, and systemic infections such as urinary tract infection and otitis media.

 

Assessing the degree of dehydration is the most important aspect of evaluating diarrhea. Dehydration can occur due to excessive loss of fluids and electrolytes through diarrhea, which can lead to serious complications. Therefore, it is important to identify and manage dehydration early on to prevent complications

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with signs of lethargy, poor feeding, and slow skin pinch return should be classified as having severe dehydration and managed urgently as per IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old female presents to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness and weakness. She reports a history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting for weight control. Arterial blood gas analysis reveals the following: (FMGE JAN 2025)

 

  • pH: 7.50
  • PaCO₂: 48 mmHg
  • HCO₃: 33 mmol/L

 

What is the most likely acid-base disturbance in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has metabolic alkalosis due to:

 

  • Elevated pH (> 7.45), indicating alkalemia.
  • Elevated HCO₃ (> 26 mEq/L), indicating metabolic alkalosis.
  • Clinical history of vomiting, which leads to the loss of chloride (via gastric acid - Hcl), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.
  • Binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting suggests that the patient may suffer from bulimia nervosa, a psychiatric illness.
  • Compensatory increase in PaCO₂ (normal: 35-45 mmHg), as per expected compensation using the Modified Winter's formula for Metabolic Alkalosis:
    • Expected PaCO₂ = 0.7 × HCO₃ + 20 (or) 0.9 × HCO₃ + 16
    • In this case, let us use the second one: 0.9 × 33 + 16 = 45.7 mmHg (± 2)
      So the expected range would be 44-48 mm Hg. 
    • The patient’s PaCO₂ of 48 mmHg falls within the expected range. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic acidosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low pH (<7.4) and low HCO₃ (<24)

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: Incorrect, as the patient’s pH is 7.5 (alkalotic) and in acidosis pH would generally be low (< 7.4)

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: Incorrect, as this would present with low PaCO₂ (< 40) and high pH (>7.4)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic vomiting results in loss of chloride (in the vomitus), resulting in hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic Alkalosis is usually characterized by elevated pH and HCO₃, with appropriate respiratory compensation (elevated PaCO₂ - due to hypoventilation).

choices.text: Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days
Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days
Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding fetal circulation is incorrect ? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anatomical closure of foramen ovale is by 3 to 5 days

 

The foramen ovale is an opening in the interatrial septum that allows blood to flow directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the lungs. After birth, as the baby begins to breathe and the lungs expand, the pressure in the left atrium increases relative to the right atrium, causing the flap-like valve of the foramen ovale to close.

 

Functional closure, where the valve is pressed shut due to the pressure difference between the atria, usually occurs immediately after birth. Anatomical closure, where the tissue actually grows together and seals the foramen, typically occurs within the first year of life, but not as quickly as 3 to 5 days. Hence, this statement is false.

 

Usually it takes anywhere between 1 to 12 months for the anatomical closure of foramen ovale

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anatomical closure of ductus venosus is by 3 to 7 days:

 

  • The ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the liver and flow directly to the heart.
  • After birth, the ductus venosus constricts and eventually closes, typically within a few days to a week. It becomes a fibrous cord known as the ligamentum venosum.

 

Option C. Right umbilical vein is absent:

 

  • In fetal circulation, there are two umbilical arteries and one umbilical vein. The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus. It's noteworthy that only the left umbilical vein persists, while the right one regresses early in development. Hence, this statement is accurate.

 

Option D. Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus is by 2 to 3 weeks:

 

  • The ductus arteriosus is a vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the descending aorta. It allows blood to bypass the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional for breathing.
  • After birth, increased oxygen concentration and decreased levels of certain prostaglandins cause the ductus arteriosus to constrict. Functional closure usually happens within the first couple of days after birth, and it undergoes anatomical closure (becoming the ligamentum arteriosum) typically within the first few weeks to months of life.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anatomical closure of the foramen ovale takes 1 month to a year.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: A female patient with a BMI of 35 kg/m2 presents to you with a skin lesion in the axilla as shown below. Which of the following condition is she most likely to be suffering from? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metabolic syndrome

 

  • The skin lesion shown in the image of axilla with velvety textured skin is indicative of Acanthosis nigricans. In this case, the patient is most likely suffering from Metabolic syndrome based on the diagnosis.

 

Acanthosis nigricans

  • It is characterized by thickened, gray-brown velvety plaques seen in flexural areas such as the back of the neck, axillae, inframammary creases, waist, and groin.
  • The release of epidermal growth factors in the affected area is the causal mechanism.
  • Acanthosis Nigricans may be benign or linked to a malignancy.

 

 

Acanthosis nigricans can also be seen in the following:

 

  • Multiple seborrhoeic keratoses
  • Drugs like nicotinic acid (Use for hyperlipidaemia treatment)
    • Other conditions associated with metabolic syndrome include polycystic ovarian syndrome, sleep apnea & non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.
    • The condition is managed by dietary & lifestyle modifications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism:

  • Hypothyroidism primarily manifests with symptoms such as fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, bradycardia, alopecia and dry skin. It doesn't typically lead to velvety skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans.

 

Option C. Addison’s disease:

  • Addison's disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, leads to symptoms like fatigue, weight loss, low blood pressure, salt craving, and hyperpigmentation. However, the hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's is more diffuse and not restricted to velvety changes in the axilla.

 

Option D. Hyperparathyroidism:

  • This condition primarily results from an overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), leading to elevated calcium levels in the blood. Symptoms include kidney stones, bone pain, and fatigue. Skin changes like Acanthosis nigricans are not a typical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acanthosis nigricans is marked by a velvety darkening of the skin in body folds.
  • There's a notable link between obesity, acanthosis nigricans, and metabolic syndrome, with the latter condition often being a visible indicator of insulin resistance.
  • Recognizing acanthosis nigricans is vital as it can be a marker of underlying systemic issues that may require comprehensive medical evaluation.

 

References –

Harrisons principle s of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 390, 2933,2934, 2936, 2970, 2971, 3086, 3150, 3151, 3154, 3155, 3156, 3173, 3175

Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2022 Page no 1157

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Chapter 147, Page no 147.14-147.15

Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition, Page no 391

questions.text: Plasmodium species that commonly affects the brain:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Falciparum

 

Explanation

 

Plasmodium falciparum is known for its ability to cause severe malaria, including cerebral malaria, which affects the brain. This species can lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and other neurological symptoms due to its ability to adhere to the endothelium of blood vessels in the brain, causing blockage of blood flow and resulting in cerebral symptoms.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Vivax: Generally causes milder forms of malaria and is less likely to cause cerebral involvement.

 

Option C. Malaria: Known for chronic malaria but rarely causes cerebral symptoms.

 

Option D. Ovale: Typically associated with milder forms of malaria and does not commonly cause cerebral complications.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Plasmodium falciparum is the species most commonly associated with cerebral malaria, affecting the brain.

questions.text: Which of the following effects of puberty are not mediated by estrogen? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hair growth

 

  • Hair growth (Pubarche): The development of axillary and pubic hair is not mediated by estrogen. It occurs due to testosterone in both sexes.
  • Estrogen effects: Estrogen plays a crucial role in various aspects of puberty, including:
    • Breast development (thelarche)
    • Development of internal genitalia
    • Menarche
    • Regulation of growth spurt
    • Epiphyseal closure
    • Cervical mucus plug formation

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen is responsible for the secretion of cervical mucus.

 

Option C. Vaginal cornification: Estrogen promotes the cornification (maturation) of the vaginal epithelium.

 

Option D. Menstruation: Estrogen is critical in regulating the menstrual cycle and the onset of menarche.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hair growth during puberty is mediated by testosterone, not estrogen. Estrogen is responsible for breast development, internal genitalia development, menarche, growth spurt regulation, epiphyseal closure, and cervical mucus secretion.

 

Ref: Page no 531, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is not decreased in Nephrotic Syndrome? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Fibrinogen

 

Explanation:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is characterized by increased glomerular permeability resulting in heavy proteinuria (>3.5g/day), leading to hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema. In this condition, there is significant urinary loss of proteins, particularly those with smaller molecular weight. However, fibrinogen is not decreased in nephrotic syndrome - it is actually increased as part of the acute phase response and due to increased hepatic synthesis.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Transferrin: Transferrin is decreased in nephrotic syndrome. Nephrotic syndrome leads to significant urinary loss of proteins, including transferrin, which has a molecular weight smaller than albumin, making it readily filtered through damaged glomeruli.

 

Option B. Ceruloplasmin:  Ceruloplasmin levels are decreased in nephrotic syndrome due to urinary losses similar to other plasma proteins that are filtered through the damaged glomerular filtration barrier.

 

Option C. Albumin:  Albumin is significantly decreased in nephrotic syndrome. Hypoalbuminemia is a cardinal feature of nephrotic syndrome, resulting from urinary protein losses exceeding the liver's capacity to synthesize new albumin.

 

Option D. Fibrinogen: Fibrinogen is not decreased but actually elevated in nephrotic syndrome. This occurs as part of the acute phase response and due to increased hepatic synthesis that compensates for the loss of other proteins. The larger molecular weight of fibrinogen also makes it less likely to be filtered through the damaged glomeruli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome results in decreased levels of many plasma proteins (including albumin, transferrin, and ceruloplasmin) due to urinary losses, but fibrinogen levels are typically increased due to compensatory hepatic synthesis and its larger molecular size, contributing to the hypercoagulable state often seen in these patients.

choices.text: Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches

questions.text: A patient presents with repeated infections from the lesion shown in the image. The correct statement in relation to the image is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Derived from 1st and 2nd arches

 

Given the location of the lesion near the ear and the recurrent infections which are characteristic of a preauricular sinus, the correct statement is Option C. Derived from 1st and 2nd arches.

 

These lesions are ectodermal in origin and are related to the developmental defects of the first and second branchial arches, which also contribute to the formation of the auricle (external ear).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. "Derived from first cleft" refers to structures that develop from the first branchial cleft in embryonic development. External ear structures, such as the external auditory canal, are derived from the first cleft, but preauricular sinuses are not typically included in this category.

 

Option B. "Derived from pouch of 1st and 2nd arches" refers to internal structures of the ear that can be affected by branchial pouch anomalies. However, preauricular sinuses are not associated with the internal structures derived from the pouches.

 

Option D. "Derived from 3rd and 4th arches" is incorrect for preauricular lesions. The third and fourth branchial arches contribute to the development of parts of the hyoid bone and the structures of the neck, not the external ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preauricular sinuses or cysts are congenital lesions derived from the first and second branchial arches and are associated with the external ear, often presenting with recurrent infections

choices.text: Enteroaggregative E. coli produces Heat stable Enterotoxin EAST-1.
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause haemolytic uremic syndrome.
Enteropathogenic E. coli acts by invading enterocytes.
Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a frequent cause of travelers’ diarrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning infections with Escherichia coli is false? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Enteropathogenic E. coli acts by invading enterocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) does not act by invading enterocytes. EPEC causes disease through a characteristic "attaching and effacing" mechanism where it adheres closely to intestinal epithelial cells and causes destruction of microvilli, but does not actually invade the cells. Instead, it remains extracellular, forming distinctive pedestals on the surface of enterocytes. This non-invasive pathogenesis is fundamentally different from truly invasive pathogens like Shigella or Enteroinvasive E. coli that penetrate and multiply within host cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enteroaggregative E. coli produces Heat stable Enterotoxin EAST-1 - This statement is true. EAEC does produce EAST-1 (enteroaggregative heat stable enterotoxin-1), which contributes to its pathogenesis. EAEC is characterized by its distinctive "stacked-brick" pattern of adherence to epithelial cells and can cause persistent diarrhea.

 

Option B. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause haemolytic uremic syndrome - This statement is true. EHEC (which includes serotype O157) produces Shiga toxin that damages vascular endothelial cells, particularly in the kidneys. This can lead to hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), characterized by microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure.

Option D. Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a frequent cause of travelers' diarrhea - This statement is true. ETEC is indeed the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. It produces heat-labile toxin (LT) and/or heat-stable toxin (ST) that stimulate excessive fluid secretion in the small intestine, resulting in watery diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The pathogenic mechanisms of E. coli vary significantly among different pathotypes: EPEC attaches without invasion, EHEC produces Shiga toxin causing vascular damage, ETEC produces enterotoxins leading to secretory diarrhea, and only Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) truly invades and multiplies within enterocytes.

questions.text: A 1-year-old baby was brought to the hospital with burn injuries on the right side of the body, including the upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg, mostly on the front. What is the estimated burn percentage? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 15-25%

 

Explanation:

 

To calculate the burn percentage in infants, the Lund & Browder chart is used.

 

  • In children surface area of Head is more, and  Lower limbs less as compared to adults:
    • Head is “18% - Age”; 
    • Each lower limb is “14% + (0.5 X Age)”
  • Above rule applicable till about 9 years of age (because after that almost similar to adults, so rule of 9 can be used)
  • Other Body Parts (Trunks, Upper limbs): same proportion of body in child as that of Adults
  • So in a 1 year child:
    • Head: 18%- 1= 17% (Front 8.5% + Back 8.5%)
    • Each Lower limb: 14% + 0.5 (1)= 14.5% (Front 7.25% + Back 7.25%) 
    • Chest: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Abdomen: 18% (Front 9% + Back 9%): Same As Adults
    • Each Upper limb: 9% (Front 4.5% + Back 4.5%): Same As Adults

    • Perinium: 1%: Same As Adults

       

Calculating Burn Area for the Right Side (Front Only) for a 1 year child

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-10% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is too low.

 

Option C. 25-35% : Incorrect. The actual burn area is 17%, so this estimate is high.

 

Option D. >50% : Incorrect. This would require extensive burns covering most of the body, which is not observed in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants, the burn percentage is calculated differently than in adults, using the Lund & Browder chart. In this case, burns affecting the only right side of body and only on front on upper limb, chest, abdomen, and leg contribute to 15-25% total body surface area (TBSA)​

questions.text: A 51-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with complaints of hematuria. Upon examination, he is found to be normotensive and has pedal edema. Further investigations reveal a lack of glycosuria and a creatinine level of 9. A renal biopsy is performed, and the results are shown below. Which of the following investigations should be conducted to identify the underlying disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anti GBM antibodies

 

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPG) is suspected based on the clinical history and microscopy showing crescents. Among the options presented, anti-GBM antibody testing should be performed because it is part of the RPGN work-up. 

 

HISTOLOGY:

 

Glomeruli — Regardless of the underlying cause, all forms of RPGN exhibit pathognomonic 'crescents' on the inside of Bowman's capsules. Crescents compress the glomerular tuft and obliterate the Bowman's space.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANA: Antinuclear antibody (ANA) testing is used for diagnosing autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which is more typically associated with Type II RPGN. It is not the primary investigation for Type I RPGN.

 

Option C. HIV RNA: This test is used for detecting HIV infection. While HIV can cause kidney disease, it is not specifically associated with the pathology seen in this case.

 

Option D. Urine immunoelectrophoresis: This test is used to detect abnormal proteins in the urine, such as in multiple myeloma. It is not relevant for diagnosing RPGN, specifically Type I RPGN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Testing for anti-GBM antibodies is crucial in the diagnosis of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) with crescents on histology, particularly for identifying Type I RPGN (anti-GBM disease).

questions.text: A farmer suffered from a subcutaneous wound on the dorsum of the foot which later involved the subcutaneous tissue and produced a discharging ulcer. Microscopic examination of the discharge showed gram-positive filamentous rods with branching. The organism responsible is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nocardia

 

 

The patient's condition suggests a subcutaneous infection that has progressed to involve deeper tissues, leading to a discharging ulcer. The key diagnostic clue here is the microscopic finding of gram-positive filamentous rods with branching, which is characteristic of Nocardia. Nocardia is a type of actinomycete, a group of gram-positive bacteria known for their branching filamentous structure. This presentation is consistent with actinomycetoma, a type of mycetoma caused by bacteria, as opposed to eumycetoma, which is caused by fungi.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida: Candida is a yeast, not a gram-positive filamentous rod. It typically presents as budding yeasts and pseudohyphae rather than branching rods, making it an incorrect option for this diagnosis.

 

Option B. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, which presents with ulcerative lesions along lymphatic channels. It does not appear as gram-positive filamentous rods, making it inconsistent with the given microscopic findings.

 

Option C. Histoplasma: Histoplasma is a dimorphic fungus that appears as intracellular yeast forms within macrophages. It does not have the filamentous, branching rod structure observed in this case, eliminating it as a possible answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases involving subcutaneous infections with gram-positive filamentous rods and branching, consider Nocardia as the responsible organism, particularly in the context of actinomycetoma.

questions.text: The adult form of echinococcus is seen in which of the following? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dog

 

The adult form of echinococcus is seen in dogs and other canis which are its definitive hosts.

 

The larval stage is passed in intermediate hosts such as sheep, cattle, goat, swine, horse, camel, and man.

 

Man acts as an accidental intermediate host (dead end).

 

Human infection follows the ingestion of eggs due to the intimate handling of dogs or by eating raw vegetables or other food contaminated with dog feces.

 

Note: Humans can become accidental definitive hosts, second intermediate hosts, or paratenic hosts for spirometra. These are cestodes belonging to the Diphyllobothriidae family. They cause a condition called sparagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cat: Incorrect, as cats are not typical definitive hosts for Echinococcus species.

 

Option C. Swine: Incorrect, swine serve as one of the intermediate hosts, not as definitive hosts where the adult tapeworms reside.

 

Option D. Sheep: Incorrect, similar to swine, sheep act as intermediate hosts where larval stages develop, not as definitive hosts for the adult form of the tapeworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dogs are the definitive hosts for the adult form of Echinococcus, underscoring the importance of proper hygiene and preventive measures in areas where these animals are common to minimize the risk of transmission and subsequent human infection.

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Identify the condition and the instrument:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

 

RULE OF IMMOBILISATION

 

  • Immobilise one joint above and 1 joint below the main target
  • Femur fracture: Fixation at hip joint and knee joint
  • Tibia fracture: Fixation at knee joint and ankle joint
  • Periarticular Knee fracture: Fixation at hip joint and ankle joint
  • Peri- and intra-articular fractures about the knee are frequently managed with joint-spanning external fixation before definitive treatment.
  • With a systematic approach, a near-anatomic reduction with respect to length, alignment, and rotation can be obtained.

 

KNEE SPANNING EXTERNAL FIXATOR

 

  • A joint-bridging external fixator is fixed to the femur and the tibia while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged).
  • Provisional reduction is achieved with distraction.
  • When external fixation is used to bridge the knee joint, it is always only for temporary fixation. Prolonged immobilization will lead to difficulties with knee mobility.
  • It is rapidly applied without need for intraoperative x-rays and can be adjusted later.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia fracture, Ilizarov fixator. The most stable external fixation for distal tibial fractures is usually composed by:

 

  • One fully circular ring with tensioned wires attached to the distal tibial articular segment
  • Two proximal fully circular rings to provide stable anchorage for the distal ring
  • An extension for the foot and ankle, and particularly for intraarticular fractures
  • 3-4 connecting rods between each ring

 

The proximal rings can be anchored with Schanz screws or tensioned wires. Wires are usually used in cancellous bone. Wires attached to a circular ring are typically tensioned at 100 to 130 kg-force.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

A spanning external fixator is used for stabilization of open and closed fractures, mainly intraarticular fractures of the lower extremity, around the knee and ankle joints.

questions.text: A resident physician sustained a needlestick injury while collecting a blood sample from a patient with HIV. It has been decided to provide the physician with post-exposure prophylaxis. What would be the most suitable course of action among the options below? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine+ Tenofovir+ Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Dose - Tenofovir (300 mg) + Lamivudine (300 mg) + Dolutegravir (50 mg) as 1 tablet/drug OD

 

Duration of PEP is 28 days, irrespective of Regimen type

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: At what gestational age can congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) typically be diagnosed via fetal ultrasound? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 Weeks

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH) are commonly diagnosed antenatally, most frequently during the second trimester ultrasound, typically around 18-24 weeks of gestation. While some cases can be identified earlier, like during the dating scan or as early as 10-12 weeks, and others may not be detected until the third trimester or even postpartum, the majority are discovered during the second trimester ultrasound. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 9 Weeks: This is too early for CDH diagnosis. At 9 weeks, fetal anatomical structures are still developing and not sufficiently differentiated to allow reliable detection of diaphragmatic defects. The diaphragm and thoracic structures are not adequately developed or visible on ultrasound at this early stage.

 

Option B. 15: While CDH can be detected at 15 weeks, in majority of cases, it is detected after 20 weeks

 

Option D. 30 Weeks: This is quite late for initial diagnosis of CDH. While some cases may remain undetected until the third trimester (which begins at 28 weeks), this represents delayed rather than typical diagnosis. Most cases of CDH should be identified during second-trimester anatomical surveys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia can typically be diagnosed via ultrasound as early as 14-15 weeks but the typical time of diagnosis is between 18-24 weeks.

choices.text: Fetal lung fluid
Maternal plasma

questions.text: Major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

 

Explanation:

 

  • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.
  • Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to amniotic fluid in the first trimester through transcutaneous flow, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.

 

Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fetal urine is the major contributor to amniotic fluid volume post 20 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Mannitol salt agar
Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar
Sorbitol MacConkey agar

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate other E. coli species from E. coli O157: H7? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

E.coli O157: H7 can be differentiated from other E.coli species using sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

There are more than 150 serotypes of Shiga toxin-producing E.Coli (STEC). Of these, 0157:7 is the most common type. Unlike most other E.Coli serotypes, the STEC 0157:H7 does not use sorbitol and produces clear colonies on the Sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

O157: H7 strains also are negative for -glucuronidase using the substrate 4-methylumbelliferyl-B-glucuronide test. More than 90 per cent of other E. coli tests positive with this substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mannitol salt agar: This medium is primarily used for the isolation of Staphylococcus species because it contains high concentrations of salt, inhibiting most other bacteria.

 

Option B. Xylose lysine deoxycholate agar: Used for the isolation of Salmonella and Shigella species, which are also important enteric pathogens.

 

Option D. CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) medium: Designed for urinary tract infections to inhibit the swarming of Proteus species and allow the differentiation of other urinary pathogens based on lactose fermentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is critical for distinguishing E. coli O157 from other E. coli strains due to its unique inability to ferment sorbitol, helping guide appropriate public health responses and treatment options during outbreaks of foodborne illness.

questions.text: Which of the following are Methanol poisoning derivatives? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formic acid + Lactic acid

 

Methanol (CH3OH) is metabolized in the body by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase into formaldehyde (HCHO). This formaldehyde is further converted into formic acid (HCOOH), which is a primary toxic metabolite responsible for the harmful effects of methanol poisoning, including metabolic acidosis, visual disturbances, and organ damage.

 

Furthermore, formic acid inhibits the electron transport chain, particularly at complex IV (cytochrome C oxidase). This inhibition disrupts ATP production, leading to increased levels of NADH. Due to this blockage, pyruvate is converted to lactate, causing the accumulation of lactic acid, another metabolite associated with methanol poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Formic acid + Oxalic acid: Oxalic acid is not a metabolite of methanol poisoning but rather of ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Option C. Glycolic acid and Oxalic acid: Both glycolic acid and oxalic acid are metabolites of ethylene glycol poisoning, not methanol poisoning. Hence, this choice is incorrect.

 

Option D. Oxalic acid and Lactic acid: Oxalic acid is not a derivative of methanol poisoning; it is associated with ethylene glycol poisoning. Therefore, this combination is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methanol poisoning primarily results in the formation of formic acid and lactic acid as toxic metabolites.

questions.text: Which of the following leukotrienes is not a vasoconstrictor? ( NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Leukotriene B4

 

Explanation: 

 

Leukotriene B4 (LTB4) is primarily a potent chemotactic agent and activator of neutrophils, causing aggregation and adhesion of neutrophils to venular endothelium. Unlike the other leukotrienes listed (C4, D4, and E4), LTB4 does not function as a vasoconstrictor in the inflammatory response. Instead, it primarily mediates leukocyte recruitment and activation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Leukotriene C4 - This is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that causes intense vasoconstriction, bronchospasm, and increased permeability of venules. It is part of the slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis (SRS-A).

 

Option B. Leukotriene D4 - Similar to LTC4, it is a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene that functions as a vasoconstrictor and bronchospasm inducer. It is also part of SRS-A and contributes to increased vascular permeability.

 

Option C. Leukotriene E4 - This is also a cysteinyl-containing leukotriene with vasoconstriction properties similar to LTC4 and LTD4. It is part of SRS-A and contributes to the inflammatory response.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leukotriene B4 differs from LTC4, LTD4, and LTE4 in that it primarily functions as a chemotactic agent for leukocytes rather than causing vasoconstriction, making it a key mediator in leukocyte recruitment during inflammation.

choices.text: Testing all the dogs for rabies
Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs
Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance

questions.text: While numerous animals play a role in the transmission of rabies, dogs stand out as the most common ones. Moreover, the impact of this disease is often more in children. Given this understanding, what approach would be both economically efficient and rational to reduce the occurrence of rabies? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Reduce stray dog population and vaccinate all dogs

 

Since dogs are the primary source of infection, the most cost-effective (and logical) strategy would be Elimination of stray dogs and taking a step towards mass immunization. This approach directly addresses the primary source of infection and helps break the transmission cycle of the rabies virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testing all the dogs for rabies: Not economically efficient due to the large number of dogs and the high cost of testing. It also does not prevent the spread of the disease.

 

Option C. Strengthening laboratory facilities: While important for diagnosis and monitoring, this does not address the primary prevention of rabies through vaccination and control of the dog population.

 

Option D. Increase capacity of healthcare workers for surveillance: Surveillance is crucial but does not directly prevent rabies transmission. It is more of a reactive approach rather than a proactive prevention strategy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reducing the stray dog population and vaccinating all dogs is the most economically efficient and rational approach to reduce the occurrence of rabies. This strategy directly targets the primary source of infection and helps prevent the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with progressive dysphagia for solids, loss of weight, and loss of appetite. A barium swallow done is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Carcinoma Esophagus

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical history of an elderly female presenting with symptoms such as progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite and weight loss along with the given barium study which shows irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction and shouldered margins. These findings are suggestive of Carcinoma Esophagus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: Is a motility disorder of esophagus and appears as a corkscrew esophagus.

 

Option B. Esophageal leiomyoma: Is a benign neoplasm of the esophagus and on barium swallow it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.

 

Option D. Esophageal webs: Refers to an esophageal constriction caused by a thin mucosal membrane projecting into the lumen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In an elderly patient presenting with progressive dysphagia for solids and significant weight loss, the presence of irregular narrowing and shouldered margins on a barium swallow is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma. Diagnostic confirmation typically requires upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (UGIE) and biopsy. For tumor staging, endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) is used for T and N staging, while PET-CT is utilized for M staging.

choices.text: Increasing renal blood flow
Increasing afferent arteriole resistance
Increasing GFR
Both B and C

questions.text: Kidney responds to shock by: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increasing afferent arteriole resistance

 

Explanation

 

Kidney responds to shock by increasing afferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Both afferent and efferent arterioles are constricted, but the efferent vessels are constricted to a greater degree. Increased resistance of afferent arterioles reduces glomerular hydrostatic pressure and decreases GFR. The glomerular filtration rate is reduced, but renal plasma flow is reduced to a larger extent, thus increasing the filtration fraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increasing renal blood flow: Incorrect because renal blood flow actually decreases as part of the body's effort to conserve blood for vital organs.

 

Option C. Increasing GFR: Incorrect as GFR decreases due to increased afferent arteriolar resistance.

 

Option D. Both B and C: Incorrect because, while increasing afferent arteriole resistance is correct, increasing GFR is not.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During shock, the kidneys respond by increasing afferent arteriole resistance, leading to reduced glomerular hydrostatic pressure and a decrease in GFR. This adaptation helps conserve blood flow and maintain systemic circulation critical for survival in shock conditions.

questions.text: An old lady complains of chronic backpain since a few months. X-ray is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoporosis

 

  • The image shows Codfish Vertebra seen in Osteoporosis.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

Codfish vertebrae

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Spondylolysis. Spondylolysis is characterized by presence of bony defect at pars interarticularis, which can result in spondylolisthesis. Most common vertebra having spondylolysis is L5. High incidence of spondylolysis in gymnasts and other athlete’s suggest repetitive injury, which may be the contributing mechanism. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage as measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate collar or broken neck on the scottie dog in spondylolysis.

 

 

Collar or broken neck on the scottie dog appearance

 

Option C. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is the forward slippage of one vertebrae upon another. It nearly always occurs between L5 and S1 (most common) or L4 and L5. Patient aged over 50 years are usually women. They always have backache or sciatica and claudication due to spinal stenosis. The extent of slippage may not be correlated with severity of pain. On examination, buttocks look flat, the sacrum appears to extend to the waist and transverse loin creases are seen. Step off can be felt when the fingers are run down the spine, secondary to prominent spinous processes of L5. With more severe slippage, the lumbosacral junction becomes more kyphotic and the trunk appears shortened with the rib cage approaching the iliac crest. Percentage of slippage is measured on lateral view and oblique radiograph demonstrate beheaded dog in spondylolisthesis (Beheaded Scottish terrier sign).

 

 

Beheaded dog appearance

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis. It is a diaphyseal dysplasia characterized by failure of bone resorption due to functional deficiency of osteoclast. The bone contains increased number of osteoclasts but these do not resorb bone as evidenced by absence of ruffled borders and clear zones and are unable to respond to PTH. Due to functional deficiency of osteoclasts, calcified chondroid (cartilage) and primitive woven bone persists down into metaphysis and diaphysis leading to osteosclerosis and increased brittleness of bones (marble bone disease). Malignant osteopetrosis (congenital form) is autosomal recessive (AR, 11q13) and late onset osteopetrosis tarda (adolescence/adult form) is AD (1P 21). Intermediate form is AR. Autosomal dominant osteopetrosis is diagnosed in adult asymptomatic patients. It may present with mild anemia, pathological fractures, premature osteoarthritis, and rarely osteomyelitis of mandible. Autosomal recessive malignant osteopetrosis presents at birth or in early infancy because of obliteration of marrow cavity by bony overgrowth, resulting in inability of bone marrow to participate in hematopoiesis. Pancytopenia develops resulting in abnormal bleeding, easy bruising, progressive anemia, and failure to thrive. Fragile, brittle bones, and Pathological fractures are seen. Laboratory parameters are serum calcium low, serum PTH high, serum phosphate low and serum ALP high. Radiological hallmark is increased radiopacity of bones. There is no distinction between cortical and cancellous bone, because intramedullary canal is filled with bone. Rugger jersey spine is seen on radiograph. Treatment is bone marrow transplant.

 

 

 

Marble bone appearance

 

 

Rugger jersey spine

 

Educational objective:

 

The image shown in the question is the radiological feature seen in osteoporosis, called as codfish appearance of vertebra.

choices.text: Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity

questions.text: Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defect in DNA helicase

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is due to a defect in DNA helicase.

 

This rare genetic disorder is characterized by premature aging, with patients typically experiencing symptoms associated with aging at an accelerated rate. The defective gene product in Werner syndrome is a DNA helicase, a protein that plays a key role in DNA replication and repair by unwinding the double helix structure of DNA.

 

 

A defect in this enzyme leads to the rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage, which can mimic the cellular aging process. This chromosomal damage is believed to contribute to the Clinical features of Werner syndrome, such as premature graying and hair loss, thinning and wrinkling of the skin and hyperpigmentation, cataracts, osteoporosis, Short Stature, Metabolic Abnormalities and an increased risk of cancer.

 

The diagnosis of Werner syndrome is typically based on clinical features, family history, and genetic testing. There is no cure for Werner syndrome, and treatment is primarily supportive and focused on managing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased telomerase activity: Increased telomerase activity typically prevents telomere shortening, which is not associated with the premature aging seen in Werner syndrome.

 

Option C. Increase in length of telomere due to decrease in telomerase activity: Decreased telomerase activity leads to shortened telomeres, not an increase in length. However, telomere lengthening is not a feature of Werner syndrome.

 

Option D. Reduced free radicals: Reduced free radicals would theoretically reduce oxidative damage and potentially slow aging. This is not related to the premature aging observed in Werner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Premature aging in Werner syndrome is primarily due to a defect in DNA helicase, leading to rapid accumulation of chromosomal damage and the manifestation of aging-related symptoms at an accelerated rate.

choices.text: Atrophy of pons with preservation of midbrain
Atrophy of both pons and midbrain
Atrophy of midbrain with preservation of pons

questions.text: Progressive Supranuclear Palsy is characterized by: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Atrophy of midbrain with preservation of pons

 

Explanation: 

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is an atypical parkinsonian syndrome characterized by midbrain atrophy while the pons remains relatively preserved. This disorder presents with progressive truncal rigidity, disequilibrium with frequent falls, and difficulty with voluntary eye movements, particularly affecting vertical gaze. Additional common symptoms include nuchal dystonia (neck stiffness), pseudobulbar palsy, and a mild progressive dementia. The pathologic hallmark of PSP is the presence of tau-containing inclusions in neurons and glial cells in the brain stem and deep grey matter structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrophy of pons with preservation of midbrain - This pattern is more characteristic of multiple system atrophy (MSA), particularly the cerebellar variant (MSA-C), where pontine atrophy is a prominent feature while the midbrain may be relatively spared.

 

Option B. Atrophy of both pons and midbrain - While some neurodegenerative conditions may affect both structures, PSP specifically shows predominant midbrain atrophy with relative preservation of the pons.

 

Option D. Atrophy of fronto-temporal region - This pattern is characteristic of frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD), which presents with behavioural changes and language deficits rather than the movement disorder seen in PSP.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Progressive supranuclear palsy is characterized by selective midbrain atrophy with relative sparing of the pons, manifesting clinically as a distinctive atypical parkinsonian syndrome with vertical gaze palsy, postural instability, and falls.

questions.text: A woman in her early 40s comes to your clinic, displaying a winding, pronounced swelling that covers the left region of her scalp and face, as visible in the provided image. Upon physical examination, you notice the swelling exhibits a rhythmic pulsation. When listening to the area with a stethoscope, a sound indicative of turbulent blood flow - a bruit - is heard. What could be the most probable diagnosis in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cirsoid Aneurysm

 

The above image is suggestive of a Cirsoid aneurysm.

 

  1. Definition: Cirsoid aneurysms, also known as arteriovenous fistulas or arteriovenous malformations, are abnormal connections between arteries and veins without the usual intervening capillaries.
  2. Common locations: They most commonly occur in the scalp and face, although they can occur in other locations in the body.
  3. Causes: They can be congenital (present at birth) or acquired, often as a result of trauma.
  4. Symptoms: Cirsoid aneurysms often present as a pulsatile mass, sometimes accompanied by a bruit (a sound heard over an artery due to turbulent blood flow). They can cause cosmetic concerns, headaches, and in severe cases, bleeding.
  5. Diagnosis: They can be diagnosed through physical examination and imaging studies such as ultrasound, CT, or MRI. Angiography can provide a detailed view of the blood vessels.
  6. Treatment: Treatment options include surgical excision, embolization (blocking off the abnormal vessels), or a combination of both. The choice of treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm, and the patient's overall health status.
  7. Complications: If left untreated, they can result in complications such as bleeding, ulceration, and, rarely, heart failure due to the increased blood flow through the malformation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neurofibromatosis:

 

  • Location: Neurofibromatosis (NF) is a genetic disorder that can affect multiple systems, including the skin and nerves.
  • Symptoms: Symptoms vary but can include skin tumors (neurofibromas), café-au-lait spots, and neurological problems

 

 

Option B. Liposarcoma:

 

  • Location: Liposarcoma is a type of soft tissue sarcoma that typically arises in fat cells in various parts of the body, including the limbs and abdomen.
  • Causes: The exact cause is often unknown, but some genetic factors may contribute. Symptoms: Symptoms may include a painless lump, swelling, or pain in the affected area.

 

Option D. Varicocele:

 

  • Location: Varicoceles are dilated veins in the scrotum, specifically in the spermatic cord. Causes: Varicoceles often develop due to faulty valves in the testicular veins, which allow blood to pool in the scrotum.
  • Symptoms: They may cause a dull ache or discomfort in the scrotum, especially after prolonged standing.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cirsoid aneurysms are arteriovenous malformations commonly found in the scalp and face, presenting as pulsatile masses with associated bruits. Proper diagnosis and treatment are essential to prevent complications such as bleeding and cosmetic concerns.

choices.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus
Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.

 

 

After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.

 

Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.

 

Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

choices.text: Cigarette smoking is a risk factor
Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

questions.text: All of these are characteristic features of pancreatic carcinoma except: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carcinoma of body of pancreas often present with jaundice

 

Patients with carcinoma of the head of the pancreas, not the body develop jaundice. This is due to obstruction of the biliary tract.

 

Etiology of pancreatic carcinoma

 

  1. Heavy cigarette smokers have higher incidence than the non-smokers.
  2. Diet with high total caloric value and high consumption of animal proteins and fats is related to higher incidence of pancreatic cancer. Obesity is a risk factor for pancreatic cancer.
  3. Chemical carcinogens: Individuals exposed to β-naphthylamine, benzidine and nitrosamines have higher incidence of cancer of the pancreas.
  4. Diabetes mellitus: Patients of long-standing diabetes mellitus have a higher incidence.
  5. Chronic pancreatitis patients are at increased risk.
  6. H. pylori infection has been reported to have association with pancreatic cancer.
  7. Genetic factors have been found to have association with pancreatic cancer e.g. its occurrence in first-degree relatives in 10% cases, occurrence in certain hereditary syndromes (Lynch, FPC, HNPCC).

 

Obstructive jaundice is more often and early in the course of disease in cases with carcinoma head of the pancreas (80%), and less often in cancer of the body and tail of the pancreas (as they do not impinge on the biliary duct)

 

Two features are characteristic of pancreatic cancer:

 

  • Highly invasive (even “early” invasive pancreatic cancers extensively invade peripancreatic tissues)
  • Elicits an intense non-neoplastic host reaction composed of fibroblasts, lymphocytes, and extracellular matrix (called a “desmoplastic response”).

 

Dense stromal fibrosis accompanies the invasive cancer, and there is a proclivity for perineural invasion within and beyond the organ. Lymphatic and large vessel invasion are also commonly seen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cigarette smoking is a risk factor: Directly linked to higher incidence rates of pancreatic carcinoma.

 

Option C. They elicit an intense desmoplastic response: Refers to the fibroblastic proliferation in the stroma surrounding the tumor, a hallmark of pancreatic cancer.

 

Option D. Perineural invasion is common: Indicates the aggressive nature of pancreatic cancer, with frequent invasion of nerves by cancer cells, contributing to pain and complex management challenges.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While pancreatic carcinomas are generally associated with intense desmoplastic responses and perineural invasion, jaundice is specifically linked more with carcinoma at the head of the pancreas rather than the body or tail.

questions.text: A woman, who is 5 days postpartum, presented with tearfulness, mood swings, and occasional insomnia. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum blues

 

Postpartum blues, or "baby blues," typically present within a 3-5 days post-delivery with mood swings, tearfulness, and mild insomnia. These symptoms resolve within a week or two.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Postpartum depression: Is more severe and persistent, lasting beyond 2 weeks, often requiring intervention.

 

Option C. Postpartum psychosis: Is a rare, severe condition manifesting with hallucinations, delusions, and potential risk to the infant.

 

Option D. Postpartum anxiety: Involves excessive worry about the baby's well-being, often without the characteristic mood swings of the blues.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Postpartum blues (or "baby blues") is a mild, transient mood disturbance that affects up to 30-75% of postpartum women. Symptoms include mood lability, tearfulness, sadness, and sleep disturbances. It typically occurs within the first week (3-5 days) after delivery and resolves spontaneously within days to weeks. Mainstay of management is reassurance, support, and education.

 

Reference: Textbook of Women’s Reproductive Mental Health, Page No 352

questions.text: Which of the following medications has been associated with an increased risk of cardiac mortality? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rofecoxib

 

Rofecoxib (a COX-2 inhibitor) has been associated with increased cardiac mortality. NSAIDs, especially selective COX-2 inhibitors, create a small but definite increased risk of myocardial infarction and mortality in patients with ischemic heart disease. When NSAID use is unavoidable in IHD patients, clinicians should select agents with the lowest cardiovascular risk profile and use them at the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metoprolol: Metoprolol is a selective β1-blocker that reduces mortality in patients with ischemic heart disease. Beta blockers are first-line therapy for managing stable ischemic heart disease and have demonstrated benefits in reducing mortality and reinfarction rates after myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. Fenofibrate:  Fenofibrate has not been documented as increasing cardiac mortality in IHD patients. It functions primarily to raise HDL cholesterol and lower triglycerides as part of lipid management therapy.

 

Option D. Losartan: Losartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) that is recommended for patients with IHD. ARBs are preferred agents for hypertension control in stable ischemic heart disease patients, especially those with reduced ejection fraction (<50%), diabetes mellitus, or chronic kidney disease.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

NSAIDs, particularly COX-2 inhibitors like rofecoxib, increase cardiovascular risk in patients with ischemic heart disease and should be avoided when possible in this population.

questions.text: In a nuclear family, the oldest person is 67 years old, his wife is 59 years old. They have a son who is 30 years old, and the son’s wife is 27 years old. They also have a grandchild who is 5 years old. Calculate the dependency ratio for the family: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 66%

 

The dependency ratio is a measure used to assess the pressure on the productive population (those typically considered to be of working age, usually between 15 and 65 years old) from the non-productive population (those considered to be dependents, usually below 15 and above 65 years old).

 

DR is also known as Societal Dependency ratio (SDR)

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

In this scenario, the family consists of:

 

  • Dependents: 2 (A child of 5 years old and elderly 67 years old)
  • Working-age individuals (15-65 years): 3 (59 years old wife; 30 year old son and 27 year old Son’s wife)

 

Thus, the dependency ratio is calculated as:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dependency ratio is calculated as the number of dependents (below 15 years and above 65 years) divided by the number of working-age individuals (15-65 years), multiplied by 100.

 

Dependency ratio measures the ‘need for society to provide for its’ younger and older groups’

questions.text: Relieving pressure of pop off valve in this device is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30-40 cm H2O 

 

The image shows an Ambu bag, which is used to provide positive pressure ventilation to patients. The pop-off valve, also known as a pressure release valve, is a safety feature that prevents the delivery of excessive pressure to the patient's lungs. This valve is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O, which is sufficient to ventilate the patient without causing barotrauma, which is damage to the lungs from excessive pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pop-off valve in a manual resuscitator is typically set to relieve pressure at 30-40 cm H2O to ensure safe and effective ventilation without causing lung damage.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hepatitis C

 

Cryoglobulinemia, a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins in the blood that precipitate at cold temperatures, is most commonly associated with Hepatitis C infection. This association is due to the immune response to the virus, which can lead to the production of these abnormal proteins. Hepatitis C-related cryoglobulinemia can result in a variety of symptoms, including rash, joint pain, and kidney problems.

 

Other causes:

 

  • Infection: Hep B, C, HIV
  • Autoimmune Disease: Sjogren, SLE
  • Malignancy: MGUS, Myeloma, CLL

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cancer: There is no established link between ovarian cancer and cryoglobulinemia. While malignancies can be associated with cryoglobulinemia, ovarian cancer is not typically among them.

 

Option C. Diabetes: Diabetes is not associated with cryoglobulinemia. While diabetes can cause a wide range of vascular and immunological issues, it does not directly cause the production of cryoglobulins.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: While certain hematologic malignancies like multiple myeloma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia can be associated with cryoglobulinemia, lymphoma is not as commonly linked compared to Hepatitis C.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Most common cause a/w Cryoglobulinemia is hepatitis C

questions.text: Primary adrenal insufficiency causes all of the following, except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased protein breakdown

 

Explanation:

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) involves impaired production of glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and adrenal androgen precursors. While glucocorticoid deficiency can affect protein metabolism, it actually leads to decreased protein breakdown (catabolism), not increased. Glucocorticoids normally promote protein catabolism, so in their absence, protein breakdown is reduced rather than increased.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low blood pressure: This is a classic feature of primary adrenal insufficiency. Mineralocorticoid deficiency causes sodium wasting and volume depletion, resulting in hypotension and often postural hypotension, which can be profound in adrenal crisis.

 

Option B. Decrease in extracellular fluid (ECF): This is correct for primary adrenal insufficiency. Aldosterone deficiency leads to sodium loss and water excretion, reducing ECF volume. This contributes to the hypotension seen in Addison's disease and is part of the clinical presentation.

 

Option C. Decreased sodium to potassium ratio: This is accurate for primary adrenal insufficiency. Mineralocorticoid deficiency leads to increased potassium retention and sodium wasting, resulting in a decreased Na:K ratio. Hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are common laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease) is characterized by decreased protein catabolism (not increased), hypotension, decreased ECF volume, and a decreased sodium to potassium ratio due to deficiency of glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.

questions.text: Regarding tumor lysis syndrome, which of the following is NOT a typical laboratory finding?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated calcium levels

 

Explanation:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hypocalcemia (low calcium), not elevated calcium. This occurs due to reciprocal depression of serum calcium in response to hyperphosphatemia, which results from massive tumor cell breakdown and release of intracellular phosphate. The hypocalcemia can cause severe neuromuscular irritability and tetany. Additionally, calcium phosphate deposition in the kidneys can contribute to renal failure.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Elevated potassium levels: Hyperkalemia is a hallmark finding in TLS. Potassium is the principal intracellular cation, and massive destruction of malignant cells leads to hyperkalemia. This electrolyte abnormality in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.

 

Option C. Elevated uric acid levels:  Hyperuricemia is a characteristic finding of TLS. Effective treatment kills malignant cells and leads to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids. Uric acid can precipitate in the renal tubules, leading to renal failure.

 

Option D. Elevated phosphate levels: Hyperphosphatemia is typical in TLS. The release of intracellular phosphate pools by tumor lysis produces a reciprocal depression in serum calcium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumor lysis syndrome presents with a characteristic tetrad of laboratory abnormalities: 

 

 

along with potential development of acute renal failure. The hypocalcemia is a consequence of hyperphosphatemia due to the inverse relationship between serum phosphate and calcium levels.

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

 

IV fluids are the next best management as the patient is in shock and needs immediate correction. ABG here could show HAGMA secondary to type A lactic acidosis or ketoacidosis. Hence, ABG wouldn’t help in the diagnosis here. Shock in patient with DKA is not common and suggest an underlying sepsis as excess glucotoxicity causes shift of H2O to the intravascular compartment. IV fluid bolus is given in the emergency immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin therapy is critical in the management of DKA, it should only be started after initial fluid resuscitation has been commenced and any electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, have been assessed and addressed.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: While ABG can provide valuable information about the severity of acidosis and help guide management, it is not the immediate next step before ensuring adequate fluid resuscitation.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: An insulin bolus can potentially exacerbate hypokalemia in the setting of DKA. Fluid resuscitation and stabilization should precede any insulin bolus or infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

questions.text: The most common site of primary structural defect in cases of inborn error of metabolism is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary structure

 

Explanation: 

 

The most common site of primary structural defect in inborn errors of metabolism is at the level of the primary structure - the amino acid sequence of the protein. Inborn errors of metabolism typically result from genetic mutations that alter the encoding of amino acids in proteins, particularly enzymes. These primary structural changes lead to altered amino acid sequences that then cascade to affect higher levels of protein structure and function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary structure: Secondary structure (α-helices, β-sheets) is derived from the primary structure and is not directly encoded by genes. While secondary structure is often disrupted in metabolic disorders, this is a consequence of primary structure defects rather than the initial defect itself.

 

Option C. Tertiary structure: The tertiary structure represents the complete three-dimensional folding of a polypeptide. While tertiary structural abnormalities occur in inborn errors of metabolism, they result from alterations in the primary amino acid sequence.

Option D. Quaternary structure: Quaternary structure involves the association of multiple polypeptide chains. Though quaternary structural problems can occur in some metabolic disorders, they typically arise as consequences of primary structural defects in one or more constituent polypeptides.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inborn errors of metabolism fundamentally arise from genetic mutations that directly alter the primary structure (amino acid sequence) of proteins, which then leads to cascading effects on protein folding, function, and metabolic pathways.

questions.text: Which one of the following conditions causes increased GFR? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased renal perfusion / RPF

 

Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR) is the rate at which blood is filtered in the kidneys. Several factors can influence GFR, including arteriolar resistance, arteriolar dilation, hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule, and renal perfusion.

 

Increased renal perfusion / RPF: Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) enhances the blood flow into the kidneys and consequently increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries. This increase in pressure promotes filtration and increases GFR. Therefore, increased renal perfusion leads to an increased GFR.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Afferent arteriolar resistance: Increasing afferent arteriolar resistance constricts the inlet to the glomerulus, decreasing renal plasma flow and hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, which reduces GFR.

 

Option B. Efferent arteriolar dilation: Dilation of the efferent arteriole reduces resistance to blood flow out of the glomerulus, lowering hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries and decreasing GFR.

 

Option C. Increase Bowman's capsule hydrostatic pressure: Increased pressure in Bowman's capsule counteracts the filtration pressure, reducing the net filtration pressure and decreasing GFR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased renal perfusion (renal plasma flow) increases the hydrostatic pressure in the glomerular capillaries, thereby increasing the GFR

questions.text: A pregnant lady with 34 weeks of amenorrhea has the following findings: LDH - 700 IU/L, platelets - 75,000/ mm3, serum bilirubin - 1.5 mg/dL, SGOT - 200 U/L, SGPT - 150 U/L, and BP - 140/96 mm Hg. Her coagulation profile and renal function tests are normal. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HELLP syndrome

 

HELLP Syndrome:

 

  • The given clinical scenario with elevated liver enzymes (SGOT and SGPT), elevated bilirubin, low platelet count, and hypertension is indicative of HELLP syndrome.
  • HELLP is an acronym for:
    • Hemolysis (H): Evidence of hemolysis can include elevated LDH.
    • Elevated Liver enzymes (EL): Both SGOT and SGPT are elevated.
    • Low Platelet count (LP): Platelet count is significantly reduced (below 100,000/mm³).
  • This syndrome is a severe form of preeclampsia and requires immediate medical attention.
  • Management often involves the termination of pregnancy, with steroid cover for fetal lung maturity and magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) for seizure prophylaxis and neuroprotection of the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy:

 

  • This condition typically occurs during the late second and third trimesters.
  • Diagnosis is based on the Swansea Criteria, requiring 6 or more specific findings, which often include renal impairment, liver impairment, hypoglycemia, and coagulation defects.
  • Liver biopsy would show microvascular steatosis.

 

 

Option C. Viral Hepatitis:

 

  • Viral hepatitis can occur at any gestational age and presents with jaundice.
  • It typically involves markedly elevated bilirubin and significantly raised SGOT and SGPT levels.
  • This scenario lacks the characteristic very high bilirubin levels seen in viral hepatitis.

 

Option D. Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy:

 

  • Usually occurs in the third trimester and presents with pruritus.
  • Lab findings typically show mildly elevated bilirubin, elevated SGOT and SGPT, and characteristically raised serum bile acids.
  • Renal impairment, high BP, and coagulation abnormalities are not seen in intrahepatic cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HELLP syndrome is characterized by hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count. It is a severe form of preeclampsia and necessitates urgent medical intervention.

 

Ref: Page no 1809, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following features is NOT associated with Achondroplasia? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D (Vertical Acetabular Roof)

 

Explanation: 

 

Vertical Acetabular Roof is not a radiological feature associated with achondroplasia. Achondroplasia is the most common skeletal dysplasia, characterized by rhizomelic shortening (shortened proximal limbs) due to a mutation in the FGFR3 gene. The classic radiological features include bullet-shaped vertebrae, champagne glass pelvis, and metaphyseal flaring.

 

Other Options:

  • Option A. Bullet Shaped Vertebra - This is a characteristic finding in achondroplasia, showing posterior scalloping of the vertebral bodies, giving them a bullet-like appearance.
  • Option B. Champagne Glass Pelvis - This is a hallmark pelvic configuration in achondroplasia with narrow greater sciatic notch and flared iliac wings that resembles a champagne glass.
