  • Option C. Trumpet Bone - While not always called by this specific name, the metaphyseal flaring with V-shaped metaphysis (Chevron sign) in achondroplasia gives long bones a trumpet-like appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achondroplasia presents with distinctive radiological features including bullet-shaped vertebrae, champagne glass pelvis, and metaphyseal flaring, but vertical acetabular roof is not part of this skeletal dysplasia's characteristic pattern.

questions.text: Which organ is the earliest to undergo putrefaction from the given options? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brain

 

Among the given options, the brain is the first organ to undergo putrefaction. The process of putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues and follows a specific order from early to late stages.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heart: The heart putrefies after the brain but before the kidneys.

 

Option C. Kidney: The kidneys putrefy after the heart.

 

Option D. Prostate: The prostate putrefies very late in the process, even after the kidneys.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The order of organ putrefaction (early to late) is as follows:

 

  1. Larynx and trachea
  2. Liver and lungs
  3. Brain
  4. Heart
  5. Kidney
  6. Prostate and Non Gravid uterus
  7. Skin, muscle, tendons
  8. Bones and teeth

 

Prostate and Non gravid uterus are organs which putrefy very late. The gravid uterus putrefies earlier.

 

Mnemonic: LBHK

 

L for larynx, liver, lungs, B for brain H for Heart, K for Kidney

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

choices.text: No dose adjustment is required
Add tenofovir 150 mg in the morning
Add lamivudine 300 mg in the morning
Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

questions.text: A patient with history of HIV was started on anti-retroviral therapy consisting of lamivudine 300 mg, tenofovir 150 mg and dolutegravir 50 mg once daily at night. Few weeks later, he developed tuberculosis and was started on anti-tubercular drugs. Which of the following dose adjustment may be required in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

 

Adjustment of ARV regimen with concomitant ATT:

 

  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + 1NNRTI (EFV)–based regimen has to be given 2HRZE + 4HRE–based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued without any modification.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + DTG–based regimen has to be given Rifampicin-based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued. However, since co-administered rifampicin reduces bioavailability of DTG, which can be overcome by an additional tablet of DTG 50 mg (at an interval of 12 hours with the regular dose of DTG) till the completion of ATT. Once the ATT is completed, additional tablet of DTG 50 mg should be stopped 2 weeks after stoppage of Rifampicin-containing treatment regimen.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + PI–based regimen develops TB, ART regimen has to be modified if 2HREZ + 4HRE–based ATT is co-administered.
    • If the patient has not taken DTG earlier, patient is shifted to 2 NRTIs + DLG-based regimen with twice daily DTG as discussed in last section
    • If DLG cannot be given due to any reason and boosted PIs need to continued, then rifampicin should be replaced by rifabutin

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients on a dolutegravir-based regimen who start rifampicin-based anti-tubercular therapy, an additional dose of dolutegravir 50 mg should be taken in the morning (12 hours apart from the regular dose) to maintain effective drug levels and manage HIV effectively.

questions.text: A neonate is diagnosed with gastroschisis. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgical wall repair 

 

Gastroschisis is a congenital condition where the baby is born with the intestines located outside of the body through an opening in the abdominal wall. 

 

This is the most appropriate management strategy. It involves surgical correction where the exposed intestines are placed back into the abdominal cavity and the abdominal wall defect is closed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wait and watch: This is not an appropriate strategy for gastroschisis. Without prompt surgical intervention, the exposed intestines are at risk of infection, dehydration, and injury.

 

Option C. Slowly putting it inside: While the concept of gradually reducing the bowel back into the abdominal cavity (sometimes called "silo" reduction) is a valid approach, it is performed as part of the surgical management and under controlled conditions, not as a standalone treatment.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This option is not relevant to the management of gastroschisis. There is no need to excise the bowel unless there is nonviable tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate management for a neonate with gastroschisis is immediate surgical repair to return the intestines to the abdominal cavity and close the defect in the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD as a known case of cervical cancer. On further evaluation, the pelvic side wall was found to be involved, and hydronephrosis was also seen. Identify the stage of cervical cancer. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3B

 

Stage 3B cervical cancer is characterized by the involvement of the pelvic side wall and the presence of hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney due to ureteric obstruction. In this stage, the cancer has extended to the lateral pelvic wall, and often the tumor affects the ureter, leading to obstructive uropathy. This progression indicates a significant local spread of the disease, distinguishing it from earlier stages where cancer is confined closer to the cervix or upper parts of the vagina.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2B: Stage 2B cervical cancer involves the spread of cancer into the parametrium but does not reach the lateral pelvic wall. It does not involve hydronephrosis or ureteric obstruction, which are key features distinguishing Stage 3B.

 

Option B. 3A: Stage 3A involves the spread of cancer to the lower third of the vagina without extension to the pelvic wall or causing hydronephrosis. It does not involve the pelvic side wall or ureteric complications, unlike Stage 3B.

 

Option D. 3C: Stage 3C is characterized by the spread of cancer to pelvic or para-aortic lymph nodes but does not necessarily involve the pelvic side wall or hydronephrosis. Stage 3C is further divided into 3C1 (pelvic lymph nodes) and 3C2 (para-aortic lymph nodes), differing from the pelvic side wall involvement seen in Stage 3B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of cervical cancer:

questions.text: G2 at 8 weeks diagnosed to have hyperthyroidism. What is the drug of choice? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Propylthiouracil


Propylthiouracil (PTU) is the preferred medication for treating hyperthyroidism in the first trimester of pregnancy. It is considered the safest option during this period because it minimizes the risk of congenital abnormalities. Methimazole and carbimazole are associated with a rare but serious condition called aplasia cutis, where infants are born with areas of missing skin. Iodine-131 is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy due to its radioactive nature, which can lead to fetal thyroid destruction and other complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methimazole: Although methimazole is commonly used for hyperthyroidism, it is not recommended during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its association with fetal defects like aplasia cutis, where patches of skin are absent in the newborn.

 

Option B. Carbimazole: Similar to methimazole, carbimazole is contraindicated in the first trimester due to the risk of fetal malformations, specifically aplasia cutis. It is often avoided in early pregnancy.

 

Option C. Iodine 131: This radioactive iodine treatment is absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy as it can cause severe fetal harm, including thyroid gland destruction and developmental issues, making it highly unsafe.

 

Educational Objective:


In the first trimester of pregnancy, propylthiouracil (PTU) is the drug of choice for hyperthyroidism due to its safer profile compared to other antithyroid medications.

questions.text: A high dose of folic acid should be given pre-conceptionally in women with? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Poorly controlled diabetes

 

Explanation:

 

A high dose of folic acid is recommended pre-conceptionally for women who are at a higher risk of neural tube defects. This includes women with poorly controlled diabetes, which is associated with an increased risk of congenital abnormalities, including neural tube defects. A high dose of folic acid (4 to 5 mg daily) should be started at least three months before conception to reduce this risk and to be given till 16 weeks of pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous h/o preeclampsia: The preventive strategy for women with a history of preeclampsia includes the use of low-dose aspirin (Ecosprin), not high-dose folic acid.

 

Option B. Previous preterm delivery: Management includes progesterone supplementation or considering a cervical cerclage in cases of cervical insufficiency, rather than high-dose folic acid.

 

Option C. Sickle cell anemia: While folic acid is important in hemoglobinopathies, the primary concern in sickle cell anemia is maintaining adequate folic acid levels due to increased hemolysis, but it is not specifically indicated at high doses for pre-conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Women with poorly controlled diabetes, epileptics, should receive a high dose of folic acid pre-conceptionally to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.
